conclusion: The problem involves analyzing a velocity-time graph to determine if the particle underwent variable linear motion in the first 3 seconds.
Velocity is on the y-axis (m/s) and time is on the x-axis (s) on the graph.
From t = 0 to t = 1 second, the velocity is constant at 2 m/s.
From t = 1 to t = 2 seconds, the velocity decreases linearly from 2 m/s to 0 m/s.
From t = 2 to t = 3 seconds, the velocity decreases further linearly from 0 m/s to -2 m/s.
Variable linear motion refers to motion where the velocity is changing over time.

premise: From t = 0 to t = 1 s: velocity is constant at 2 m/s.
conclusion: From t = 0 to t = 1 s, the motion is uniform linear motion.

premise: From t = 1 to t = 2 s: velocity is decreasing linearly from 2 m/s to 0 m/s.
conclusion: From t = 1 to t = 2 s, the motion is variable linear motion.

premise: From t = 2 to t = 3 s: velocity is decreasing linearly from 0 m/s to -2 m/s.
conclusion: From t = 2 to t = 3 s, the motion is variable linear motion.

premise: There are periods of both uniform and variable linear motion in the first 3 seconds.
conclusion: Overall, in the first 3 seconds, the particle underwent variable linear motion.
